The American Indian Movement (AIM) was founded in 1968 in Minneapolis, Minnesota, and its original purpose was to stop discrimination and racial profiling of American Indians by Minneapolis police officers. This activist organization quickly expanded to help Native peoples in need across the entire United States. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1972, a group of 40–50 AIM members took over the Oklahoma City office of Chickasaw Nation Governor Overton James, who also served as the State Director of Indian Education. They accused his department of not exercising sufficient control over the ways in which Oklahoma schools spent federal Indian education monies. This occupation eventually exposed the misappropriation of federal funds in the state and offered hope that such monies would be used as intended in the future—for the American Indian students of Oklahoma. Learn more about this event and AIM at bit.ly/AmericanIndianMovement.

(2012.201.B0306B.0731, Oklahoma Publishing Company Photography Collection, OHS) #AmericanIndian #AIM

On September 1, 1903, Florence Thompson was born near Tahlequah, Indian Territory (present-day Oklahoma). Thompson is best remembered as the subject of a photograph known today as “Migrant Mother.” This became one of the most iconic images of the Great Depression. Thompson died on September 16, 1983, and her gravestone epitaph reads, “Migrant Mother: A Legend of the Strength of American Motherhood.”

Photo taken by Dorothea Lange in Nipomo, California, March 1936 (Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division) #MigrantMother

#ThisDayInHistory
On August 25, 1905, Ira Hall was born in Colbert, Indian Territory. He broke barriers and defied the odds during his life as an educator, entrepreneur, and civic leader. Hall was orphaned at the age of 14, but he was determined to attend and graduate from present-day Langston University. He had to interrupt his education five times in order to earn enough money for tuition and living expenses. In 1932 Hall became one of the first three students to graduate from Langston with a bachelor’s degree in business administration. He later earned a master’s degree in educational administration from the University of Oklahoma. Read more about his life at bit.ly/IraHall.

(20699.80.44.5, State Museum/Rubye M. Hall Collection, OHS) #BlackHistory

During the summer of 1905, prominent leaders organized a constitutional convention at Muskogee with the goal of creating the State of Sequoyah. Delegates from Indian Territory wrote a constitution to create the new state, which was envisioned to be separate from Oklahoma Territory. The constitution was ratified by the voters, but Congress rejected it. Approximately two years later, Indian Territory and Oklahoma Territory joined to become the state of Oklahoma. Learn more at bit.ly/SequoyahConvention.

On August 19, 1958, members of the OKC NAACP Youth Council occupied seats at the Katz Drug Store lunch counter in downtown OKC and politely asked to be served. When denied service, the students remained seated in a peaceful protest. After three days of the student sit-in (led by Clara Luper), the management at Katz Drug Store agreed to serve them and it became an integrated lunch counter. This was the first direct action in a struggle for civil rights that would last several years. The Clara Luper Legacy Committee will host a virtual celebration of the sit-in movement tonight at 6:30 p.m. at www.claraluperlegacy.com.

On August 15, 1935, Wiley Post and Will Rogers were killed in a tragic plane crash. Both men were avid boosters of aviation and technology.
Earlier that year, Wiley Post had constructed a hybrid floatplane from a Lockheed Orion. He wanted to test the operational capabilities of the aircraft with a long-distance flight. He asked his friend Will Rogers to join him on a junket to Alaska and Siberia. Unfortunately, the hybrid Orion proved to be aerodynamically unstable. Shortly after takeoff, Post lost control of the aircraft and it crashed into the Walakpa Lagoon near Point Barrow, Alaska.

This photo was taken just before their final flight (19336.135, Wiley Post Collection, OHS) #85YearsAgo #Aviation

This photo was taken by Dorothea Lange in downtown Sallisaw, Oklahoma, in August 1936. It depicts several farmers who would often gather to socialize “while their crops burn up in the fields” (as Lange put it).
The dry weather began in the early 1930s and persisted through the early 1940s in some areas, with the most intense drought years occurring in 1934 and 1936. This decade-long drought caused economic, social, and environmental devastation throughout the region. Learn more about drought conditions in Oklahoma at bit.ly/DroughtOK.

Johnson became one of the most prominent Black attorneys in the area, and was esteemed by Creeks and Seminoles as “The Black Panther.” Due to his familiarity with the language, laws, and customs of these tribes, Johnson was able to work as an interpreter and serve in various political positions. He also spent considerable time advocating for equal rights. Learn more about his life and legacy at bit.ly/JCoodyJohnson.

#ThisDayInHistory
On July 17, 1863, the Battle of Honey Springs took place near present-day Checotah, Oklahoma. It was the largest of approximately 107 documented Civil War military engagements throughout Indian Territory. The engagement took place just two weeks after the famous Battles of Gettysburg and Vicksburg. Approximately 9,000 Union and Confederate troops, mostly American Indians and African Americans, were involved in the Battle of Honey Springs. Of those, approximately 200 total casualties were suffered. After a decisive Union victory, Confederates lost control of Indian Territory north of the Arkansas River. The Union victory also ensured federal control of Fort Gibson in Indian Territory and Fort Smith in Arkansas.

Join us tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. for a VIRTUAL Battle of Honey Springs Memorial Event over at the Facebook page for Honey Springs Battlefield and Visitor Center.

Of those, approximately 200 total casualties were suffered. After a decisive Union victory, Confederates lost control of Indian Territory north of the Arkansas River. The Union victory also ensured federal control of Fort Gibson in Indian Territory and Fort Smith in Arkansas.

On July 2, 1964, the Civil Rights Act was signed into law by President Lyndon B. Johnson. The act prohibited discrimination (on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, or national origin) in public places; provided for the integration of schools and other public facilities; and made employment discrimination illegal.
Oklahoma’s Black citizens had been fighting to end segregation and discrimination for many years prior to 1964, so this was an important victory. However, the Civil Rights Act did not end discrimination completely. There was still work to be done. Learn more and browse free resources related to the Black experience in Oklahoma at www.okhistory.org/blackhistory.

(Photos of demonstrations, sit-ins, and marches in Oklahoma from 1958 through 1964) #OKhistory #BlackHistory #CivilRights #CivilRightsAct

In June 1941, a new mural was unveiled inside the U.S. Post Office in Watonga, Oklahoma. The mural, painted by Edith Mahier, is titled “Roman Nose Canyon.” It features Cheyenne Chief Henry Roman Nose, his family, fellow tribe members, and encroaching white settlers.
Soon after the unveiling, members of the Cheyenne tribe participated in a multi-day protest outside the post office—indicating that they were not pleased with the portrayal of Chief Roman Nose and his family. Mahier defended her work, but also offered to repaint part of the mural (although she never did). Some sources indicate that the protests were part of a plan by city leaders to get media attention for developing Roman Nose State Park as a tourist destination. Learn more from the Smithsonian’s National Postal Museum at bit.ly/RomanNoseMural.

Soon after the unveiling, members of the Cheyenne tribe participated in a multi-day protest outside the post office—indicating that they were not pleased with the portrayal of Chief Roman Nose and his family. Mahier defended her work, but also offered to repaint part of the mural (although she never did). Some sources indicate that the protests were part of a plan by city leaders to get media attention for developing Roman Nose State Park as a tourist destination. Learn more from the Smithsonian’s National Postal Museum at bit.ly/RomanNoseMural.

On June 5, 1950, the U.S. Supreme Court made a ruling in the “McLaurin v. Oklahoma State Regents” case—deciding that a state university could not treat one student differently, solely because of his race.
Chief Justice Fred Vinson indicated that the treatment of George W. McLaurin at the University of Oklahoma was itself a violation of the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause. Vinson wrote: “Such restrictions impair and inhibit his ability to study, to engage in discussions and exchange views with other students, and, in general, to learn his profession.” Learn more at bit.ly/McLaurinOK.

Photo of George W. McLaurin (2012.201.B0391.0687, Oklahoma Publishing Company Photography Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #70YearsAgo

#ThisDayInHistory
On May 31–June 1, 1921, one of our country’s single worst incidents of racial violence took place in Tulsa, Oklahoma. During the course of 18 terrible hours, more than 1,000 homes and businesses were destroyed, and credible estimates of deaths range from 50 to 300. This was the Tulsa Race Massacre.
By the time the violence ended, the city had been placed under martial law, thousands of Tulsans were being held under armed guard, and the state’s second-largest African American community had been burned to the ground. One of the great tragedies of Oklahoma history, the Tulsa Race Massacre has lived on as a potent symbol of the ongoing struggle of black and white citizens to forge a common destiny out of an often troubled past. Learn more at bit.ly/TulsaRaceMassacre.

(Clockwise from top left: 15583.C / 16944 / 15583.B / 15583.A, OHS Photograph Collection) #OKhistory #99YearsAgo #TulsaRaceMassacre

On May 23, 1875, Kate Barnard was born in Nebraska, and she later moved to Oklahoma. In 1907, Barnard became the first woman elected to a statewide office in Oklahoma—an election in which women could not even vote!
As Oklahoma’s first Commissioner of Charities and Corrections, she persuaded the state legislature to adopt laws requiring compulsory education, regulating child labor, and launching a juvenile justice system. Learn more at bit.ly/KateBarnard.

On May 12, 1903, a post office was established in Supply, Oklahoma Territory (present-day Woodward County). The town was named after nearby Camp Supply—a frontier military post established in 1868. It was not until May of 1943 that the town’s name was changed to Fort Supply.
From 1938 until 1942, a dam and reservoir were constructed just south of town in the valley of Wolf Creek. At that time, it was the largest earthen dam in the United States. Learn more about the town of Fort Supply at bit.ly/FortSupplyTown.

Chilocco Indian School was a federal boarding school designed to educate, transform, and culturally assimilate American Indians. #DidYouKnow?
In April 1910, Bud and Temple Abernathy (ages 10 and 6) rode alone on horseback from Crossroads Ranch near Frederick, Oklahoma, all the way to New York City.
Jack Abernathy, father of the adventurous young boys, was a close friend of President Theodore Roosevelt and was planning to meet him in New York City. Abernathy’s sons begged him to allow them to go ahead and travel the 2,000 miles on horseback to meet their dad and President Roosevelt. The trip took the boys approximately two months and they arrived in time to ride in a parade with President Roosevelt.
And how did the boys get back home? They drove themselves in an automobile, of course! The Abernathy boys became celebrities and took several cross-country trips in the years that followed.

Photo of the Abernathy boys with their Brush automobile, 1910 (43, W. P. Campbell Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #110YearsAgo

Platt National Park was the 7th National Park established in the United States. Located near present-day Sulphur, Oklahoma, it was originally designated as Sulphur Springs Reservation in 1902. Then in June 1906, Congress re-designated it as Platt National Park. Again in 1976, it was re-designated and continues its operations today as the Chickasaw National Recreation Area. On April 19, 1995, at 9:02 a.m. a 4,800-pound ammonium nitrate–fuel oil bomb exploded in a Ryder truck parked at the north entrance of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in downtown Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring approximately 850. At the time, the bombing was the nation’s worst single act of domestic terrorism.
The governor’s office reported that 30 children were orphaned, 219 children lost at least one parent, 462 people were left homeless, and 7,000 people lost their workplace. The City of Oklahoma City’s Final Report estimated property damage to more than 300 buildings in a 48-square-block area. Learn more at bit.ly/4-19-1995.
Today, #WeRemember those who were killed, those who survived, and those changed forever by the tragedy on April 19, 1995.

Photo by Jim Argo (2012.201.B0959.0179, Oklahoma Publishing Company Photography Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #25YearsAgo #DayOfRemembrance

On April 2, 1942, Leon Russell was born in Lawton, Oklahoma. Russell was raised in Tulsa and studied classical piano from a very young age. He later became one of rock music’s greatest contributors. #DidYouKnow? There is only one county in the United States that touches five states: Kansas, Colorado, New Mexico, Texas, and its own, Oklahoma.
Cimarron County is the farthest west of the three Oklahoma Panhandle counties. It is home to the highest point in Oklahoma (Black Mesa – 4,973 feet above sea level), numerous dinosaur tracks, fossils, traces of the Santa Fe Trail, and its Kenton Caves contain artifacts that represent thousands of years of area occupation. A few of the finds include rock art, projectile points, potsherds, seeds, storage bags, cloth, and shell jewelry. Today, Cimarron County is the least populous county in Oklahoma. Learn more at bit.ly/CimarronCountyOK.

The theme for the 2020 Oklahoma History Conference is “Connecting Cultures: Exploring the Three Forks.”
Three Forks is the area of present-day Oklahoma where the Verdigris River and the Neosho (Grand) River merge into the Arkansas River. The region was a hub for European trade and settlement, and was later the site of Indian Territory’s first military outpost, Fort Gibson (est. 1824). It was the terminus of the Muscogee (Creek) and Cherokee Trail of Tears, and eventually became part of the Osage, Muscogee (Creek), and Cherokee Nations. The Texas Road and the Arkansas River functioned as main arteries for travel—serving explorers, traders, immigrants, and the military. To enlarge and explore the Three Forks map, please visit bit.ly/ThreeForksOK.

Map of the Three Forks area, sketched by Tom Meagher (WATMAP.FOREMAN.0002, Grant Foreman Collection, OHS) #OKhistory

#ThisDayInHistory
On February 22, 1912, coal miner Rufino Rodrigues saved more than 150 men (some claims have estimated 190 and others as many as 259) from a fire in the No. 5 Shaft in Lehigh, Oklahoma. After discovering the fire, and at great risk to his own safety, Rodrigues did not immediately escape the coal mine, but started a 1.5-mile journey throughout the complex to warn the unsuspecting miners of the danger. To combat the smoke he carried a water bucket to soak his wool shirt and then cover his face. Dazed from smoke inhalation, he had to be pulled out of the mine. Nine miners did not survive the blaze, but many more would have been trapped without Rodrigues’s warning.

(18032, Frederick S. Barde Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #CoalMine #Hero

On January 17, 1894, a post office was established in a town known as Lawson. But in February 1903, the post office was re-designated as Quay.
Quay was a quiet, agricultural trade center until the 1910s and 1920s (when it quickly became an oil boom town). The estimated population was 4,000 people! By the time the first federal census was taken in 1930, the town had 186 residents. As the Great Depression set in and oil production declined, people moved away. Quay was disincorporated in August 2000 and is no longer officially a town. Learn more at bit.ly/QuayOK.

#ThisDayInHistory
On January 13, 1903, legend has it that John Wilkes Booth committed suicide while staying at the Grand Avenue Hotel in Enid, Oklahoma Territory. By this time, Booth was using the name David E. George.
A doctor diagnosed the cause of death as self-administered arsenic poisoning. Later it was told that the deceased had purchased strychnine that morning at a local drug store. The body was taken to Penniman’s Furniture Store, also a funeral home. A coroner’s jury soon heard stories about this strange, locally unknown man: he was a house painter who did not know how to paint, who always had access to money but died penniless, who frequented bars and loved alcohol, who often quoted Shakespeare, who knew no one but was known by many outside Enid, and who was quoted as saying, “I killed the best man that ever lived.”
Continue reading about the Booth legend at bit.ly/BoothLegendOK.

Photo of John Wilkes Booth (courtesy of the Library of Congress)

#ThisDayInHistory On December 26, 1861, the Battle of Chustenahlah took place near present-day Skiatook, Oklahoma.
After the Muscogee (Creek) Council made a treaty of alliance with the Confederacy, a Creek leader named Opothleyahola led a mass exodus of Creeks and members of other tribes who were loyal to the Union to seek refuge in Kansas. Confederate forces followed in late 1861, which led to several battles in November and December of that year. Forced to leave most provisions behind in their haste to escape the pursuing Confederates, many American Indians suffered extreme hardships in refugee camps in Kansas. Opothleyahola died of illness there on March 22, 1863.
Learn more about the Battle of Chustenahlah at bit.ly/ChustenahlahOK.

Image of Opothleyahola (704, Mrs. Redbird Smith Collection, OHS) #OKhistory

#ThisDayInHistory
On December 24, 1924, a Christmas program was held at Babbs Switch School, approximately five miles south of Hobart, Oklahoma. Sadly, 36 men, women, and children were killed in a fire that raged through the one-room schoolhouse. Candles ignited a Christmas tree and spread to new paint on the walls. The doors were built to open inward, and when people crowded them to escape, they were trampled. This tragic fire resulted in new laws that required school exit doors to open outward.

Photo of Ray Goforth next to the historical marker in 1977 (2012.201.B0223.0180, Oklahoma Publishing Company Photography Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #95YearsAgo

Many men were trapped inside or killed by flying debris. In all, the USS “Oklahoma” lost 20 officers and 395 enlisted men. Except for the USS “Arizona,” the “Oklahoma” lost the most casualties of all ships in the harbor that day.

On November 22, 1898, Wiley Post was born near Corinth, Texas. Throughout his youth, Wiley Post’s family moved several times to small towns throughout Texas and Oklahoma. By 1920 his parents settled on a farm near Maysville, Oklahoma. Post later became a famed aviator and his experimental flights ultimately proved the value of using the east-to-west jet stream. His adventurism, record-setting flights, and aeronautical experiments blazed a pathway for modern flight. Learn more about Wiley Post in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/WileyPost.

On November 13, 1912, Mary Caroline Cole was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma. Cole was the first woman to become a licensed architect in Oklahoma.
Initially Cole had trouble breaking into this male-dominated field, but she eventually had a successful career and created new opportunities for other female architects. Mary Caroline Cole’s legacy lives on in her designs for residences, offices, and churches as well as two Tulsa fire stations.

Have you ever visited a ghost town in Oklahoma? Did you see any ghosts? 👻 Share your stories in the comments!
It is estimated that Oklahoma has had approximately 2,000 ghost towns. These towns sprang into existence and died due to economic booms and busts, the routing of railroad lines, power struggles between town promoters, and even natural disasters. Towns such as Hochatown, old Kaw City, Lugert, and Sardis disappeared when reservoirs and lakes were developed.
Ghost towns everywhere have a certain lure. Faded, weather-worn signs dangling in the wind and stone foundations of former buildings, as indications of long-forgotten settlements. Learn more about ghost towns in Oklahoma at bit.ly/OKhistoryGhostTowns.

Join us this weekend at Honey Springs Battlefield and Visitor Center for the Battle of Honey Springs Reenactments!
Education Day will be held on Friday, November 1, from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.
On Saturday, November 2, and Sunday, November 3, camps will open to the public at 10 a.m. The battle reenactments will take place at 1 p.m. Learn more at www.okhistory.org/hsb.

The Battle of Honey Springs was the largest of approximately 107 documented Civil War military engagements in present-day Oklahoma. The engagement took place on July 17, 1863, just two weeks after the famous Battles of Gettysburg and Vicksburg. Approximately 9,000 Union and Confederate troops, mostly American Indians and African Americans, were involved in the Battle of Honey Springs. #ThisDayInHistory
On October 24, 1901, Ida B. Bleini was appointed as the first postmaster of Grant, located in present-day Choctaw County, Oklahoma. The town was named to honor President Ulysses S. Grant, and can trace its origin to c. 1885 when Basil Gooding opened a store at the site.
At one time, there were as many as 30 businesses in Grant. The east-to-west Arkansas and Choctaw Railroad initially surveyed a route through Grant, but the tracks were actually laid five miles north of town. Many entrepreneurs relocated their businesses to the new rail line, and in 1902 the town of Hugo formed at that location. Learn more about the town of Grant at bit.ly/GrantOK.

(13699, OHS Photograph Collection) #OKhistory #TownsOfOklahoma

On October 21–22, 1912, the first examination for nurses was held in Oklahoma City. Seven applicants took the test.
Prior to 1907 Oklahoma statehood, nurse training was offered in hospital-based programs that prepared individuals for employment at that hospital. There was no mechanism for registration or licensure of graduates of these programs, nor were there methods to regulate the education and practice of nurses. Learn more about the history of nursing education in Oklahoma at bit.ly/NursingEduOK.

#ThisDayInHistory
On October 8, 1918, the 36th Infantry Division suffered approximately 1,300 casualties during a battle near Saint-Étienne, France. Two men who entered service from Oklahoma, Samuel M. Sampler and Harold L. Turner, received the Medal of Honor for their bravery on this day. Both Sampler and Turner served in the 142nd Infantry Regiment, 36th Division.
And #DidYouKnow? The 36th Division had more American Indians than any other unit. Most were assigned to the 142nd’s Company E. When the commander of the 142nd suspected that Germans were wiretapping communication lines, several of the Choctaws from Company E helped by transmitting messages in their native language. This led to their designation as Code Talkers. Learn more about the Code Talkers in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/CodeTalkersOK.

Photo of Company E, 142nd Infantry, 36th Division, while in France (21336, OHS Photograph Collection)

#DidYouKnow? Council Grove, a 3.5-square-mile area located within the present-day city limits of Oklahoma City, was the site of much activity during the 1800s. It was a location for inter-tribal gatherings, a timber reserve for Fort Reno, the site of a trading post established by Jesse Chisholm in 1858, and eventually had homesteaders surround it after the Land Run of 1889.
Want to learn more about the area’s unique history? On Thursday, October 17, at 7 p.m. OHS Executive Director Dr. Bob Blackburn will give a free presentation about Council Grove at Castle Falls Restaurant & Venue. This event is hosted by the WesTen District. Details can be found at bit.ly/CouncilGrove10-17-19.

#ThisDayInHistory #175YearsAgo
On September 26, 1844, the first issue of the “Cherokee Advocate” was printed. This newspaper was published by the Cherokee Nation in present-day Tahlequah, Oklahoma. Like its predecessor, the “Cherokee Phoenix,” it was published weekly in Cherokee and English to provide Cherokees with information about their people and the United States. When it started publication, it was the country’s only tribal paper. It was soon joined by the “Choctaw Intelligencer” in 1850 and the “Chickasaw Intelligencer” in 1854. Learn more about the “Cherokee Advocate” in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/CherokeeAdvocate.

#DidYouKnow? Jay-Kola was an Oklahoma City staple for nearly 50 years, and served as one of the few African American bottling companies in the Southwest. Percy James and his wife Hattie may have started the company as early as 1918, but it was not listed in “Polk’s Oklahoma City Directory” until 1921. The James’s daughter Jewel claimed that her father opened his bottling plant on the advice of the owner of the OKC Coca-Cola Bottling Company, which did not deliver to the black business section. Learn more about Jay-Kola in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/Jay-Kola.

(2012.201.B0230.0111, Oklahoma Publishing Company Photography Collection, OHS) #OKhistory

On September 23, 1911, the town of Broken Bow was incorporated. Although Broken Bow was located on land previously owned by the Choctaws, it did not receive its name from its local American Indian roots. Instead, it was named after Broken Bow, Nebraska, the home of Herman and Fred Dierks, who had moved to southeastern Oklahoma to establish the Choctaw Lumber Company. Learn more about Broken Bow in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/BrokenBowOkla.

On September 16, 1893, the Cherokee Outlet Opening took place. It was present-day Oklahoma’s fourth and largest land run.
Economic pressures plus poor planning and inadequate enforcement by federal agencies made it even more chaotic than earlier runs, resulting in massive fraud, widespread suffering, and a number of deaths. Learn more about the Cherokee Outlet Opening in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/LandRun1893.

On September 7, 1931, a new bridge across the Red River (located between Colbert, Oklahoma, and Denison, Texas) was finally opened to traffic. The free bridge had been at the center of a dispute that saw involvement from both the Oklahoma National Guard and the Texas Rangers. Before the dispute was settled, Oklahoma Governor William H. “Alfalfa Bill” Murray declared martial law and even showed up to the scene armed with a revolver. This controversy is often referred to as the Red River Bridge War. In the end, the free bridge near Colbert remained open until 1995 (when it was demolished and replaced with a new bridge).

(20381.10, Stan Oliner Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #RedRiverBridgeWar

On August 30–31, 1975, a large music festival took place in Atoka. “48 Hours in Atoka” was Oklahoma’s answer to Woodstock and other music festivals across the country. Advance tickets were only $10, and the crowd size was estimated at 40,000 people! Performers included Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings, Jerry Lee Lewis, Freddy Fender, Jessi Colter, Larry Gatlin, Hoyt Axton, David Allan Coe, and Jerry Jeff Walker. Many music historians consider the festival in Atoka to be the beginning of the outlaw country music movement.

Photos by Fred W. Marvel (Oklahoma Department of Tourism Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #OKPOP

#ThisDayInHistory
On August 20, 1986, USPS letter carrier Patrick Sherrill reported to work at the United States Post Office in Edmond, Oklahoma. He had received a reprimand the day prior and was considered to be a disgruntled employee. As Sherrill entered the facility, he began shooting his coworkers. He killed 14 people and wounded 6 others. He then killed himself. At that time, this was the state’s largest and the nation’s third-largest mass murder committed by a single individual in a single incident. Learn more about the Edmond Post Office Massacre in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/EdmondPO.

Photo of memorial wreaths outside the Edmond Post Office (2012.201.B0408B.0185, Oklahoma Publishing Company Photography Collection, OHS) #OKhistory

#ThisDayInHistory
On August 15, 1935, Wiley Post and Will Rogers were killed in a tragic plane crash. Both men were avid boosters of aviation and technology.
Earlier that year, Wiley Post had constructed a hybrid floatplane from a Lockheed Orion. He wanted to test the operational capabilities of the aircraft with a long-distance flight. He asked his friend Will Rogers to join him on a junket to Alaska and Siberia. Unfortunately the hybrid Orion proved to be aerodynamically unstable. Shortly after takeoff, Post lost control of the aircraft and it crashed into the Walakpa Lagoon near Point Barrow, Alaska.

(9972, Lee Harkins Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #Aviation

On July 22, 1933, Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Urschel were at their home in Oklahoma City. It was a typical evening and they were playing bridge with Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jarrett. Suddenly, two armed men (one with a machine gun) interrupted their bridge game and abducted Mr. Urschel and Mr. Jarrett. This began a startling kidnapping case that evoked the new Lindbergh kidnapping laws, led to 21 convictions, coined a new name for FBI agents, and culminated in one of the first filmed trials. Learn more about the Urschel Kidnapping in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/UrschelOK.

#OKhistory #MachineGunKelly

On July 17, 1959, Governor J. Howard Edmondson signed a bill that legalized the sport of boxing in Oklahoma. Prior to that date, it was a misdemeanor to engage in a prizefight in the Sooner State.
The Oklahoma Territorial Legislature had declared in 1890 that pugilism was “a crime against the public peace” and rejected a bill to legalize boxing in 1895. Although Governor Lee Cruce used the Oklahoma National Guard to enforce the state’s prizefighting law, Oklahoma’s anti-boxing legislation was unpopular and so it was ignored. Learn more about the history of boxing in Oklahoma at bit.ly/BoxingOK.

Photo of men boxing in the barracks at Fort Reno, c. 1914 (17746, Toney Lackey Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #Boxing

On July 17, 1863, the Battle of Honey Springs took place near present-day Checotah, Oklahoma. It was the largest of approximately 107 documented Civil War military engagements throughout Indian Territory. The engagement took place just two weeks after the famous Battles of Gettysburg and Vicksburg. Approximately 9,000 Union and Confederate troops, mostly American Indians and African Americans, were involved in the Battle of Honey Springs. Of those, approximately 200 total casualties were suffered. After a decisive Union victory, Confederates lost control of Indian Territory north of the Arkansas River. The Union victory also ensured federal control of Fort Gibson in Indian Territory and Fort Smith in Arkansas.
Visit Honey Springs Battlefield and Visitor Center to learn more, and be sure to save the dates for the Battle of Honey Springs Reenactments at 1 p.m. on November 2 and 3, 2019. #OKhistory

On July 14, 1912, Woody Guthrie was born in Okemah, Oklahoma. Guthrie was one of Oklahoma’s most creative native sons. He wrote more than 1,000 songs and poems, numerous essays and articles, two autobiographical novels, and hundreds of letters. He drew more than 500 illustrations, recorded hundreds of songs, and was a major influence in the urban folk revival, in the folk rock movement, and in social protest song writing.

Photos from #ThisDayInHistory – Students and faculty at Wheelock Academy on the 4th of July, unknown year
Wheelock Academy is located near present-day Millerton, Oklahoma. It functioned as a boarding school for American Indian girls, mostly Choctaw, from 1884 to 1955. The origin of the institution dates to 1832 when a Christian missionary couple, Alfred and Harriet Wright, resumed the work they had earlier conducted among the Choctaws in Mississippi. Following Choctaw removal to Indian Territory, the Wrights established a mission station, school, and church.
Wheelock Academy was designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1965. It is nationally significant as the first academy in the Choctaw Nation and as the model that other tribes in Indian Territory used when creating their own schools. Wheelock is one of 22 National Historic Landmarks in Oklahoma. Learn more about Wheelock Mission and Academy in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/WheelockOK.

(Photos from the Sarah Ellison Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #NationalHistoricLandmark #4thOfJuly

#ThisDayInHistory
On July 1, 1834, a post office was established at Eagletown, located in present-day McCurtain County, Oklahoma. It was named for the many eagles that nested in a nearby swamp along the Mountain Fork River. Eagletown was prominent in regional history from the early 19th century and in the period of Choctaw national sovereignty from the 1830s to 1906. The Choctaw rapidly recovered from the trauma of the Trail of Tears, and Eagletown became a trading center on the much-traveled Military Trace. In addition to a store, by the 1850s there were several gristmills, a water mill, cotton gins, and a sawmill in the vicinity. A ferry also operated there on the Mountain Fork River. Many prominent Choctaw leaders chose to live in or near Eagletown. Especially notable were principal chiefs George Hudson (1860–62), Peter Pitchlynn (1864–66), and Jefferson Gardner (1894–96). Learn more about Eagletown in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/EagletownOK.

We are saddened by the passing of our friend Bob Klemme, who died on June 25, 2019. Klemme was a historian, a native of Enid, and an emeritus member of the OHS Board of Directors. He will be remembered for his efforts to preserve Oklahoma history, particularly the legacy of the Chisholm Trail. Klemme spent seven years marking the Oklahoma section of the Chisholm Trail, and he was determined to have the trail designated as a National Historic Trail. Bob, you will be missed.

#ThisDayInHistory
Late in the evening on June 24, 1901, an oil well at Red Fork Field near Sapulpa hit a gas pocket at a depth of 537 feet, and oil shot 30 feet over the top of the derrick. One of the developers panicked and sent a telegram to Joplin, Missouri, requesting help. By the next day, reports of a spectacular oil discovery filled local newspapers. In less than a week Red Fork was overrun with more than 4,000 fortune seekers clamoring for leases. Upon further investigation it was discovered that the well was only producing 10 barrels or less per day, but that did not stop the stampede to get in on the oil boom. Learn more about Red Fork Field in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/RedForkField.

Photo of an oil well near Sapulpa (23139.IO.O.F.S.1.6, Devon/Dunning Petroleum Industry Collection, OHS) #OKhistory #Oil

#ThisDayInHistory
On June 3, 1869, Grant Foreman was born in Illinois. He eventually became one of the foremost historians in Oklahoma. Foreman was trained as an attorney, and he came to Indian Territory in 1899 as a field worker for the Dawes Commission. Through this experience and subsequent legal practice he developed a thorough knowledge of the Three Forks area and the Indian tribes of eastern Oklahoma. By 1920 Foreman devoted all his attention to historical research and writing. He and his wife Carolyn also traveled extensively, researching in libraries and repositories worldwide and accumulating books for their personal library. In February 1924 he was elected to the OHS Board of Directors. Learn more about Grant Foreman in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/GForemanOK.

#ThisDayInHistory
During the course of 18 terrible hours on May 31 and June 1, 1921, more than 1,000 homes and businesses were destroyed, and credible estimates of deaths range from 50 to 300. This was the Tulsa Race Massacre—believed to be the single worst incident of racial violence in American history.
By the time the violence ended, the city had been placed under martial law, thousands of Tulsans were being held under armed guard, and the state’s second-largest African American community had been burned to the ground.
One of the great tragedies of Oklahoma history, the Tulsa Race Massacre has lived on as a potent symbol of the ongoing struggle of black and white Oklahomans to forge a common destiny out of an often troubled past. Learn more in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/TulsaRaceMassacre.

On May 29, 1897, aviator Roy Orlando Hunt was born in present-day Arapaho, Oklahoma, and spent his youth in Carter, Oklahoma. Hunt was part of a small but enthusiastic and enterprising group that developed commercial aviation in Oklahoma. Competition also enthralled Hunt, and in 1931 he set a world record for the most consecutive outside loops, 124 in 124 minutes. Learn more about Roy Hunt in “The Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture”—bit.ly/RoyHunt.

#ThisDayInHistory
On May 26, 1951, the scissor-tailed flycatcher became Oklahoma’s state bird. Despite a failed first attempt to make the bird the official symbol, the species was eventually chosen for its diet of harmful insects, its Oklahoma-centered nesting range, and by the fortunate circumstance that no other state had designated it. Learn more about our state’s official symbols at www.okhistory.org/symbols.
